::: ::: {.callout-note appearance="simple"} ## Example 4 Determine the behaviour of the function $f(x) = 2\ln(3x) - x$ when $x = 1$. Here, you will first need to differentiate the function $f(x)$ to find $f'(x)$. Then, you will need to evaluate the derivative $f'(x)$ when $x = 1$ to see how the function behaves. Using your rules of differentiation as you found above, you can say that the derivative of $2\ln(3x)$ is $2/x$, and the derivative of $x$ is $1$. Therefore, the derivative of the function $f(x) = 2\ln(3x) - x$ is $$f'(x) = \frac{2}{x} - 1.$$ You can evaluate the derivative $f'(x)$ at $x = 1$ to get $$f'(1) = \frac{2}{1} - 1 = 2 - 1 = 1$$ and so the derivative is positive at $x = 1$. This implies that the function $f(x) = 2\ln(3x) - x$ is increasing at the point $x = 1$. It also means that the gradient of the tangent to the function $f(x)$ at the point $(1,2\ln(3) - 1)$ is $1$. You can see this in the figure below. ::: ::: {.content-visible when-format="html"}
::: ::: {.content-hidden when-format="html"} ![The graph of $f(x) = 2\ln(3x) - x$, with the tangent to the graph at $(1,2\ln(3) - 1)$ illustrated, demonstrating that the function is increasing at $x = 1$.](./FiguresPNG/introtodifferentiation-fig3-3.png){width="80%" #fig-3} ::: Â  ## Summary Here's a table of derivatives that you should remember going into any further reading on differentiation.
